regular-body:
amazighprincex:

I think that a lot of hearing people are confused about how exactly lipreading works. it’s not some magical ‘cure-all’ where you learn to lipread and all of a sudden you can function with 100% accuracy in a hearing society

  • first of all, there’s a lot of ambiguity involved. only about 30 to 40% of sounds in the English language are distinguishable from sight alone— meaning that, even if you’re a lipreading expert and pick up on every single cue that it’s possible to pick up on with unfailing accuracy, you’re still only going to get 30 to 40% of the auditory information being given to you if you’re using lipreading alone. think of the sounds [m], [b], and [p]—they’re all bilabial, and you can’t tell whether a sound is nasal or voiced from sight alone. are you saying ‘mat’ or ‘bat’? who knows!
  • that being said, most d/Deaf/HoH people don’t rely on lipreading exclusively because it’s very rare that people are completely unable to hear anything. a lot of us use lipreading to supplement what information we are able to get from auditory cues (information that may be inaccurate or incomplete due to hearing loss, processing disorders, etc). so maybe with audio alone I wouldn’t be able to differentiate between the words ‘bet’ and ‘vet,’ but if I’m looking at your mouth, the difference (bilabial vs. labiodental, respectively) is pretty clear.
  • this seems obvious but apparently it’s not? in order to read your lips we need! to be able! to see! your lips!!! this means the lighting has to be good, we have to be relatively close to you, you cannot cover your mouth or face away. communicating with someone through spoken words can be really stressful and energy-consuming for us and there is no reason for us to make such a huge effort to communicate with you if you don’t have enough basic respect for us to meet us halfway.
  • basically lipreading is a bit of a guessing game where we have to associate small and fleeting lip movements with sounds that are sometimes ambiguous, consider what the context is, evaluate the probability that you said a certain word over another one, then put all the pieces together to understand what you’re saying, and we do all of this while you’re still speaking! shit’s difficult. so if someone asks you to repeat something maybe just do it and don’t get all huffy about it, thanks

also do me a favour and reblog this
